responses: Hi, I'm MeowBot! What can I help you?
Meow, please enter something.

Meow? I can't understand you.

patterns: What can you do for me?
responses:
MeowBot can provide you the information about:
1. Cat care tips
2. Cat anatomy
3. Cat health
4. Cat communication cues
5. Quirky cat behavior
6. Cat facts
7. Cat diseases

patterns: Show me some cat care tips
Tips to keep my cat healthy
Show me more cat care tips
responses:
1. Groom your cat regularly
2. Provide fresh water daily
3. Make sure you have enough litter boxes
4. Notice if your cat starts urinating outside its litter box
5. Train your cat to use a scratching post
6. Use a cat carrier in the car
7. Keep your cat's teeth clean
8. Choose a cat-friendly vet
9. Schedule regular veterinary visits
10. Spay or neuter your cat

patterns: Why is it important to groom my pet regularly?
Why should I groom my cat?
responses: Meow~, it can helps to remove the dead hair from your cat's coat so it doesnt ingest it while self-grooming and gives you the chance to notice any changes to your pet body.

patterns: Why is it important to provide fresh water daily for my cat?
Why should I provide fresh water to my cat?
responses: Meow~, clean and fresh water is essential for your cat's good health.

patterns: Why my cat don't drink water from a bowl?
Why my cat doesn't seem to drink from a bowl?
responses: Meow~, try to provide your cat a tall glass. Because some cats don't like to bend down to drink.

patterns: Why I need to make sure I have enough litter boxes?
Why enough litter boxes is important?
responses: Meow~, a general rule of thumb for litter boxes is one for each cat plus one more. To encourage good litter box habits, keep the litter boxes clean. This may mean scooping more than once per day. Regular cleaning will also help you notice any changes in your cat's urine or stool, which could indicate a health issue.

patterns: Why my cat urinate outside the litter box?
Why my cat doesn't urinate inside the litter box?
responses: Meow~, you may schedule a visit to the veterinarian because your cat may have a urinary tract infection or other medical issue.

patterns: Why I need to train my cat to use a scratching post?
Why is it important for my cat to use a scratching post?
responses: Meow~, this can prevent damage to your furniture and helps you cat  stretch it muscles and keep it's claws in top condition.

patterns: Why I need to have cat carrier im my car?
responses: Meow~, by having cat carrier, your cat will not roam freely in the car which may distract you from driving safely.

patterns: Why I need to keep my cat's teeth clean?
Why cat needs to have a clean teeth?
responses: Meow~, cats can develop tartar on their teeth, which can lead to gum disease and tooth decay if their teeth is not clean.

patterns: Why I need to have a cat-friendly vet?
responses: Meow~, a veterinarian specializing in feline health and anatomy can be a valuable ally in keeping your cat in it best possible health.

patterns: Why is it important to schedule a regular veterinary visits?
Why is it important to schedule a regular vet visits?
Why my cat need a regular vet visit?
responses: Meow~,  annual visits give the vet a chance to catch any potential feline diseases in their early stages, administer vaccines, and clean the cat's teeth. Your vet can also tell you if your cat is at a healthy weight.

patterns: Show me some cat anatomy and physiology.
Show me more cat anatomy and physiology.
responses:
1. Cats are nearsighted, but their peripheral vision and night vision are much better than that of humans.
2. Cats are believed to be the only mammals who don't taste sweetness.
3. Cats can jump up to six times their length.
4. Cats have 230 bones, while humans only have 206.
5. Male cats are more likely to be left-pawed, while female cats are more likely to be right-pawed.
6. Cats have the largest eyes relative to their head size of any mammal.

patterns: Show me some cat health and wellness.
Show me more cat health and wellness.
responses:
1. According to The Huffington Post, cats typically sleep for 12 to 16 hours a day.
2. Cats live longer when they stay indoors.
3. Cats can spend up to a third of their waking hours grooming.
4. Your cat‚Äôs grooming process stimulates blood flow to his skin, regulates his body temperature and helps him relax.
5. Spaying and neutering can extend a cat‚Äôs life.
6. Grapes and raisins, as well as onions, garlic, and chives, are all extremely harmful foods for cats.

patterns: Show me some cat communication cues.
Show me more cat communication cues.
responses:
1. A cat with a question-mark-shaped tail is asking, ‚ÄúWant to play?‚Äù
2. A slow blink is a ‚Äúkitty kiss.‚Äù This movement shows contentment and trust.
3. Cats have up to 100 different vocalizations.
4. Cats find it threatening when you make direct eye contact with them.
5. If your cat approaches you with a straight, almost vibrating tail, this means that she is extremely happy to see you.

patterns: Show me some quirky cat behaviour and why they happen.
Show me more quirky cat behaviour and why they happen.
responses:
1. Cats often attack your ankles when they‚Äôre bored.
2. Cats are very fussy about their water bowls; some prefer to ignore their bowls entirely in favor of drinking from the sink faucet.
3. Cats like to sleep on things that smell like their owners, such as their pillows and dirty laundry.
4. If you can‚Äôt find your cat, you should look in a box or a bag, as these are some of their favorite hiding spots!

1. Each cat‚Äôs nose print is unique, much like human fingerprints.
2. A cat‚Äôs learning style is about the same as a 2 to 3 years old child.
3. Cats dream, just like people do.
4. White cats with blue eyes are prone to deafness.

patterns: What is the common cat diseases?
responses:
1. Cancer
2. Diabetes
3. Feline Immunodeficiency Virus (FIV)
4. Feline Leukemia Virus (FelV)
5. Heartworm
6. High-Rise Syndrome
7. Rabies
8. Ringworm
9. Upper Respiratory Infections
10. Worms
Cats can get various kinds of cancer. The disease can be localized (confined to one area, like a tumor) or generalized (spread throughout the body).

patterns: What is the factors of cat cancer?
responses: Cancer is a ‚Äúmultifactorial‚Äù disease, which means it has no known single cause. However, we do know that both hereditary and environmental factors can lead to the development of cancer in cats.

patterns: What is the symptoms of cat cancer?
What is the sign of cat cancer?
responses:
1. Swelling
2. Persistent sores or skin infections
3. Bad breath
4. Weight loss
5. Diarrhea
6. Scaly
7. Change in behavior

patterns: How to prevent cat from getting cancer?
How to avoid cancer for my cat?
responses:
1. Keeping your cat indoors will protect her from certain skin cancers caused by repeated sun exposure and sunburn
2. Breast cancer is a common cancer for cats, but it can be avoided by having your cat spayed before her first heat cycle.
It is important to understand that diabetes is considered a manageable disorder‚Äîand many diabetic cats can lead happy, healthy lives. Some may even go into remission!

patterns: Show me the type of diabetes?
What the type of diabetes have?
responses:
Type 1 - lack of insulin production
Type 2 - impaired insulin production along with an inadequate response to the hormone

patterns: What are diabetes symptoms in cats
responses:
1. Change in appetite
2. Weight loss
3. Excessive thirst
4. Increased urination
5. Urinating in areas other than litter box
6. Dehydration
7. Unkempt hair coat
8. Urinary tract infection

patterns: Factors that make cats have diabetes
responses: The exact cause of diabetes is unknown. Genetics, pancreatic disease, certain medications and abnormal protein deposits in the pancreas can play a role in causing this disorder.
The most important factors in the development of diabetes seem to be obesity, gender (male cats are more commonly afflicted than females) and age.
To properly diagnose diabetes, your veterinarian will collect information about clinical signs, perform a physical examination and check blood work and urinalysis.
A proper diet and regular exercise can go a long way to avoid the development of feline diabetes. Aside from other negative effects, obesity is known to contribute to insulin resistance.

Cats infected with FIV may not show symptoms until years after the initial infection occurred. Although the virus is slow-acting, a cat‚Äôs immune system is severely weakened once the disease takes hold. FIV cannot be transmitted from cat to human, only from cat to cat.

patterns: What is the symptoms of FIV
responses:
1.Fever
2. Anemia
3. Weight loss
4. Poor appetite
5. Diarrhea
6. Sneezing
7. Discharge from eyes or nose
8. Behavior change
9. Skin redness or hair loss

1. FIV is mainly passed from cat to cat through deep bite wounds
2. Less common mode of transmission is from an FIV-infected mother cat to her kitten
3. Any feline is susceptible, free-roaming, outdoor intact male cats who fight most frequently contract the disease

patterns: How to prevent my cat from getting FIV
responses:
1. Keep your cat indoors
2. Avoiding any chance of contact with infected felines
3. If you walk your cat, keep him on a leash when outdoors
4. If your cat is going to be spending any time in a cattery or in a home with other felines, make sure all cats have tested negative for FIV
5. You may also want to speak to your veterinarian about the FIV vaccine and if it is appropriate for your cat

1. FIV infection is routinely diagnosed by blood testing
2. The FIV status of every cat should be known
3. Since it is possible for an infected mother cat to transfer FIV antibodies to her kittens, these kittens may test positive from their mother‚Äôs antibodies until they have cleared them from their systems

1. Medication for secondary infections
2. Healthy
3. Palatable diet to encourage good nutrition
4. Fluid and electrolyte replacement therapy
5. Anti-inflammatory drugs
6. Immune-enhancing drugs
7. Parasite control
FelV is a transmittable RNA retrovirus that can severely inhibit a cat‚Äôs immune system. It is one of the most commonly diagnosed causes of disease and death in domestic cats.

patterns: What is the symptoms of FelV
What is the sign of FelV
responses:
1. Loss of appetite and weight loss
2. Poor coat condition
3. Fever
4. Diarrhea
5. Vision problems
6. Chronic skin disease
7. Enlarged lymph nodes

patterns: How can I avoid my cat from infected FelV
responses:
1. There is a vaccine available for cats who are at risk of contracting FelV
2. As with any infectious disease, the best prevention is eliminating sources of exposure

1. Most veterinarians and shelter professionals use the ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) test, which detects antigen to the FELV virus in the bloodstream
2. Tests like the IFA (indirect fluorescent antibody) test or PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test are recommended to confirm positive ELISA test results

Spread by infected mosquitoes, heartworm is increasingly being recognized as an underlying cause of health problems in domestic cats. Cats are an atypical host for heartworms. Heartworm primarily causes lung disease in cats. It is an important concern for any cat owner living in areas densely populated by mosquitoes.

patterns: What is the symptoms of heartworm
What is the sign of heartworm
responses:
1. Persistent cough
2. Breathing difficulties
3. Depression
4. Loss of appetite
5. Weight loss
6. Sporadic vomiting
7. Lethargy
8. Sudden death

1. Several FDA-approved medications available that reliably prevent feline heartworm infection
2. Limit your cat‚Äôs exposure to mosquito-infested areas
3. Regular checkups are key to detecting early infections

1. Routine testing includes a combination of blood tests
2. When cats show signs of respiratory difficulty and heartworm is suspected, diagnosis is usually based on a cat‚Äôs history, physical examination, radiographs, echocardiogram and blood tests

Many pet parents eagerly open their windows to enjoy the weather during the summer months. Unfortunately, unscreened windows pose a real danger to cats, who fall out of them so often that the veterinary profession has a name for the complaint‚ÄîHigh-Rise Syndrome. Falls can result in shattered jaws, punctured lungs, broken limbs and pelvises‚Äîand even death.

1. Install snug and sturdy screens in all your windows
2. If you have adjustable screens, please make sure that they are tightly wedged into window frames
Rabies is a viral disease that affects the brain and spinal cord of all mammals, including cats, dogs and humans.

1. Rabies is most often transmitted through a bite from an infected animal
2. It can be passed on when the saliva of an infected animal enters another animal‚Äôs body through mucous membranes or an open, fresh wound
3. Unvaccinated cats who are allowed to roam outdoors are at the highest risk for rabies infection
4. Feral cat populations remain a reservoir host for the rabies virus
Visit your veterinarian regularly or taking vaccination

patterns: What is the symptoms of rabies
responses:
1. Change in behavior
2. Increased vocalization
3. Loss of appetite
4. Weakness
5. Disorientation
6. Paralysis
7. Seizures
8. Sudden death

patterns: Is there any other ways to diagnose rabies?
responses:
1. There is no accurate test to diagnose rabies in live animals
2. The direct fluorescent antibody test is the most accurate test for diagnosis, but it can only be performed after the death of the animal

patterns: What can I do if my cat interacts with a rabid animal?
responses:
1. Put gloves on to protect yourself from infection
2. Call your veterinarian for an immediate appointment
3. A cat who is up to date with his vaccinations and who has been bitten by a possibly rabid animal should also be given a rabies booster vaccine immediately and kept under observation for 45 days
4. Contact local animal control officers if the animal who bit your pet is still at large; they will be best able to safely apprehend and remove the animal from the environment

Although the name suggests otherwise, ringworm isn‚Äôt caused by a worm at all‚Äîbut a fungus that can infect the skin, hair and nails. Not uncommon in cats, this highly contagious disease can lead to patchy, circular areas of hair loss with central red rings. Also known as dermatophytosis, ringworm often spreads to other pets in the household‚Äîand to humans, too.

patterns: What is the symptoms of ringworm
What is the sign of ringworm
responses:
1. Skin lesions that typically appear on the head, ears and forelimbs
2. Cause flaky bald patches that sometimes look red in the center
3. In mild cases, there may be localized areas of redness or simply dandruff, while more severe infections can spread over a cat‚Äôs entire body
4. It‚Äôs possible for a pet to carry ringworm spores and not show any symptoms whatsoever

1. Any cat can develop ringworm, but kittens less than a year old and geriatric cats are most prone to infection
2. Long-haired cats and those who are immunocompromised are also more susceptible
3. Ringworm can quickly spread in shelters or other crowded environments
4. Warm and humid conditions tend to promote ringworm infections

1. Since some cats show few or no symptoms, a diagnosis of ringworm is rarely made just by looking at the skin
2. A veterinarian may use an ultraviolet light to diagnose ringworm, or may examine a fungal culture taken from a cat‚Äôs hair or skin cells
3. Frequently vacuum to rid the house of infected hairs and skin cells
3. Skin biopsy and microscopic exam are sometimes also performed

1. A veterinarian may prescribe a shampoo or ointment that contains a special medication to kill the fungus
2. Treat the cat‚Äôs environment to prevent infection from recurring
3. Frequently vacuum to rid the house of infected hairs and skin cells
4. Wash the infected animals‚Äô bedding and toys with a disinfectant that kills ringworm spores
A cat‚Äôs upper respiratory tract‚Äîthe nose, throat and sinus area‚Äîis susceptible to infections caused by a variety of viruses and bacteria.

patterns: What are the causes of Upper Respiratory Infections
Reason of my cat infected by URIs
responses:
1. Viruses are the most common causes of upper respiratory infections (URIs) in cats
2. These viruses can be transmitted from cat to cat through sneezing, coughing, or while grooming or sharing food and water bowls
3. There are also upper respiratory infections in cats that are primarily caused by bacteria. Chlamydia and Bordetella‚Äîcommonly found in shelters and areas with multiple cats‚Äîare two such bacterial infections.
4. Once infected, cats can become carriers for life, and though they may not show clinical signs, they can still transmit the viruses to others

patterns: How to prevent Upper Respiratory Infections
How can I avoid my cat from getting URIs
responses:
1. Keep your cat indoors to minimize the risk of exposure to infected animals
2. Properly isolate infected cats to protect other pets living in the same environment
3. Keep your cat up to date on vaccines as recommended by your vet
4. Practice good hygiene and wash your hands thoroughly when handling multiple cats

patterns: What is the symptoms of Upper Respiratory Infections (URIs)
What is the sign of Upper Respiratory Infections (URIs)
responses:
1. Sneezing
2. Congestion
3. Runny nose
4. Cough
5. Fever
6. Rapid breathing
7. Open-mouth breathing

patterns: How to diagnose Upper Respiratory Infections (URIs)
How to detect Upper Respiratory Infections (URIs)
Ways to identify Upper Respiratory Infections (URIs)
responses:
1. Age, vaccination status and physical condition all play a role in a cat‚Äôs susceptibility to upper respiratory infections
2. Cats who live in multi-cat households or shelters are most susceptible
3. Veterinarians have found that stress plays a role in causing outbreaks of URI, and cats in any shelter, cattery or boarding facility are generally experiencing high levels of stress
4. Cats who have recovered from URI can become carriers, and may experience recurrences when stressed
5. Certain breeds like Persians and other flat-faced breeds have a predisposition to develop upper respiratory infections due to their facial structure

1. Medications
2. Isolation
3. Rest
4. Support with fluids
5. Nutritional support

patterns: Please explain to me about worms
responses: Cats can acquire a variety of intestinal parasites, including some that are commonly referred to as ‚Äúworms.‚Äù Infestations of intestinal worms can cause a variety of symptoms. Some feline parasitic worms are hazards for human health as well.

patterns: How can I avoid my cat from getting worms
responses:
1. Keep your cat indoors to avoid exposure to infected cats, rodents, fleas and feces
2. Make sure your home, yard and pets are flea-free
3. Practice good hygiene and wear gloves when changing cat litter or handling feces. It‚Äôs also important to frequently dispose of stool
4. Ask your veterinarian to recommend an appropriate internal parasite treatment or prevention program for your cat

patterns: What is the symptoms of worms
What is the sign of worm?
responses:
1. Diarrhea
2. Bloody stool
3. Weight loss
4. Vomiting
5. Constipation
6. Anemia
7. Coughing
8. Trouble breathing

Not all dewormers eradicate all types of worms.  Your veterinarian will determine the type of worm(s) infestation(s) your cat has, and prescribe the best course of treatment.  Your veterinarian will also be able to tell you if the dewormer should be repeated, and when.
